titleStmt.title: THE EFFECTS OF RESOURCE CUES ON DELAY DISCOUNTING

affiliation.orgName: School of Humanities and Social Science
The Chinese University of Hong Kong
School of Humanities and Social Science

analytic.title: THE EFFECTS OF RESOURCE CUES ON DELAY DISCOUNTING

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

abstract.p: Studies have shown that people are sensitive to resource cues which signal body-energy budgets or resource availability. These signals adaptively shift their preferences when making intertemporal choices between a smaller but immediate reward and a larger but delayed alternative. Although recent research results are heterogeneous, there has been no article to date summarizing the effect of different types of resource cues on preference in intertemporal choice. Through a meta-analytic approach, we examined the putative signaling effects of two types of resource cues-blood glucose and appetitive stimuli-on delay discounting, which gauges the preference for intertemporal decision-making. We extracted 44 effect sizes from 26 articles, and these indicated that high levels of blood glucose (e.g., feeling satiated or less hungry) decrease delay discounting (d = 0.26, 95% CI [0.06, 0.46]) while exposure to appetitive stimuli increases delay discounting (d =-0.28, 95% CI [-0.51,-0.05]). In addition, the effect of blood glucose was moderated by the type of reward, showing that the signaling effect on delay discounting was stronger for food in contrast to nonfood rewards such as money. Overall, the results suggest that both internal signals and external cues about resource situations serve as forecasting signals for regulating resource budgets. Furthermore, the signaling effect is domain-specific, with its magnitude dependent on the relevance of rewards to individuals' goals of resource acquisition and conservation.

div.head: THE EFFECTS OF RESOURCE CUES ON DELAY DISCOUNTING 3
The Signaling Effects of Blood Glucose and Appetitive Stimuli on Delay Discounting: A Meta-Analysis
div.p: Human minds are best construed as consisting of many specialized modules that have evolved to solve recurrent adaptive challenges that arose during the Pleistocene Epoch (Tooby et al., 1992). These modules, or psychological adaptions, are attuned to different ecological cues and can process these environmental inputs in order to trigger adaptive cognitions and behavior that are beneficial to survival or reproduction (Li et al., 2018;Schaller et al., 2017). Among the most significant issues pertaining to survival is the allocation of bioenergy budget. Since all energy budgets of an organism are finite, individuals make tradeoffs between consumption and conservation based on external and internal resource cues. For example, in order to acquire resources for survival, humans could have evolved a psychological adaption that motivates them to eat when tasting sweetness, which is a reliable cue of carbohydrates and nutrient (Li et al., 2018). This line of reasoning implies that humans are sensitive to proximate resource cues, and adjust their goal priorities to properly allocate resources that are essential to survival (Lu et al., 2022;Schaller et al., 2017;Wang, 2018).

A typical resource allocation task is intertemporal decision-making. In each trial of the task, participants choose between a smaller but sooner food or monetary reward and a larger but later alternative (Frederick et al., 2002). Preferences in intertemporal choices are gauged by delay discounting, with higher discounting rates indicating a larger devaluation of delayed rewards. Since food and money are essential resources for survival, natural selection should favor psychological THE EFFECTS OF RESOURCE CUES ON DELAY DISCOUNTING 4 adaptations that allocate resources across time intervals in the dynamic interaction with resource cues that maximize fitness (Griskevicius et al., 2011;Rao et al., 2015).

Rival views suggest that delay discounting reflects self-control (Duckworth & Kern, 2011;Rachlin, 1974), and being future-oriented (e.g., choosing larger but later alternatives) is always rational. This dismisses the biological reality that human needs are based on instantaneous resource availabilities. For starved individuals, it is more adaptive to increase foraging behavior and allocate more resources to the present in order to fuel the caloric budget.

Research over the past 20 years supports the position that delay discounting is regulated by both external and internal resource cues (Li, 2008;Skrynka & Vincent, 2019;Wang & Dvorak, 2010). The findings of these studies reveal two strands. The first strand showed that blood glucose serves as an internal cue of body-energy budget and regulates resource allocations (Kirk & Logue, 1997;Koehler et al., 2021;Lu et al., 2019;Wang et al., 2018). Low blood glucose levels, as when one experiences hunger, could increase delay discounting. A second strand emphasizes the signaling effect of appetitive stimuli (Li, 2008;Yeomans & Brace, 2015), which increase delay discounting for caloric and monetary resources.

In the first strand, the landmark study by Wang and Dvorak (2010) found that participants who consumed a sugary drink showed lower delay discounting of monetary rewards. As the evidence accumulated, the authors proposed the resource signaling hypothesis and argued that blood glucose is an anticipatory signal of bodyenergy budget (Wang, 2018;Wang et al., 2018). Specifically, low levels of blood THE EFFECTS OF RESOURCE CUES ON DELAY DISCOUNTING 5 glucose increase the desire for resource acquisition while high levels of blood glucose increase the tendency for resource conservation. Moreover, subsequent studies indicated that the signaling effect is domain-specific (Orquin & Kurzban, 2016;Skrynka & Vincent, 2019). The effect of food deprivation or blood glucose on delay discounting is more salient for food because it better addresses the current energy crunch. Money, which is considered as a modern derivative of food (Briers et al., 2006), is also regulated for it help people acquire bioenergetic resources indirectly.

Regarding the second strand of findings, previous work has documented that being exposed to appetitive stimuli such as cookie scents makes people more presentoriented in intertemporal decision-making (Li, 2008). In ancestral environments when resources were scarce, appetitive stimuli like sweetness were valid predictors of subsequent energy availability (Hill et al., 2014;Li et al., 2018). Therefore, these stimuli increase the salience and urgency of the desire for resources (Katz & Naug, 2015;Wang et al., 2018). Two hypotheses, the cephalic phase hypothesis (Forzano & Logue, 1994) and the resource signaling hypothesis (Wang, 2018), distinguish between the effects of food cues and food deprivation. Specifically, these hypotheses predict that the availability of food leads to the prioritization of caloric needs and means that sooner rewards in intertemporal choices are more attractive either via an elevation in insulin levels (Forzano & Logue, 1994) or through deactivating brain regions that are active when making complex decisions (Wang et al., 2018). These theoretical predictions are supported by both animal and human experiments. For example, individuals consuming non-caloric sweeteners subsequently increase their THE EFFECTS OF RESOURCE CUES ON DELAY DISCOUNTING 6 calorie intake (Hill et al., 2014;Swithers & Davidson, 2008) or delay discounting (Wang et al., 2018;Wang & Dvorak, 2010).

Based on the review of literature, we have summarized distinct two strands of studies regarding the signaling effect of resource cues on delay discounting. In particular, this focuses on the effect of blood glucose and the effect of appetitive stimuli. However, several issues remain unaddressed and a research synthesis is required before fully accepting the signaling effects. First, the signaling effect of glucose or hunger is far from definitive. A meta-analysis (Orquin & Kurzban, 2016) revealed that lower blood glucose led to a higher time discounting rate. Nevertheless, their meta-analysis omitted evidence that opposes the glucose effect (e.g., de Ridder et al., 2014). In addition, more recent findings have reported null effects (Finley et al., 2019;Muda et al., 2021;Sawicki et al., 2019), rendering the glucose effect open to doubt. Second, although scattered empirical studies have illustrated that food cues can increase delay discounting, they have tended to focus on separate stimuli like scents or glucose rinse. Importantly, there is no study to date that has integrated the existing findings. Therefore, the current study integrated effects of visual, olfactory, and gustatory stimuli on delay discounting, providing a comprehensive review of the effect of appetitive stimuli on delay discounting.

div.head: Method Search Strategies and Inclusion Criteria
div.p: Eligible articles were identified through a two-stage process. First, the THE EFFECTS OF RESOURCE CUES ON DELAY DISCOUNTING 7 references of relevant studies were screened. Second, the Scopus database was searched using the following keywords: ABS("temporal discounting" OR "delay discounting" OR intertemporal OR "time discounting" OR "discounting rate" OR "rates of discounting" OR "delay of gratification") AND ABS("food deprivation" OR "food deprived" OR calories OR metabolic OR metabolism OR diet OR hunger OR hungry OR glucose OR meal OR satiation OR appetitive OR appetite OR beverage OR ingest OR ingestion OR sugar OR sucrose OR rinse OR sweetener OR aspartame).

• Studies were included if they met all of the following criteria: the study implemented an experimental manipulation on resource cues, either through glucose/sweetener ingestion, glucose mouth-rinse, food deprivation, exposure to visual/olfactory/ gustatory food stimuli
• the dependent variable was delay discounting or an index indicated the preference of allocating resources across intervals (e.g., saving vs. spending)
• the study was conducted among human participants and did not reported on clinical samples
• the study was published in English.

During the first stage, 19 eligible studies were identified. The literature search in the second stage identified 220 papers, among which three additional articles matched our inclusion criteria. The 22 included studies were conducted between 1991-2021. One article was not published (Button, 2017). extracted data from the figure via WebPlotDigitizer (Rohatgi, 2014).

Our screening identified both the between-subjects and the within-subjects design, for which the metrics of the standardized mean difference are incomparable due to the different standard deviation used in calculation (Morris & DeShon, 2002).

To guarantee comparable scaling of the Cohen's d, we used the raw-score metric, which is the most prevalent scaling in practice and reflects the mean difference between the experimental and the control groups, relative to the pooled standard deviation. Effect sizes calculated in the metric of within-subjects design (the change score metric) can be transformed into the raw-score metric using the following formula:

where d is the Cohen's d, is the correlation between pre-and posttest scores, and the subscripts BS and WS represents the between-subjects and the within-subjects design, respectively. For studies adopting a within-subjects design and not reporting the correlation coefficient, we imputed a correlation of 0.5 following the suggestion of THE EFFECTS OF RESOURCE CUES ON DELAY DISCOUNTING 9 Cumming (2012). This practice might be conservative for the effect size estimate, because the correlation often exceeds 0.5 (Morris & DeShon, 2002).
To calculate sampling variance of in the raw-score metric, we used the formula proposed by Morris and DeShon (2002):
where n is the sample size, df represents the degrees of freedom (df equals n -1 for repeated measures), and c is a bias function:
This method gives higher weights to the within-subjects design, especially when the correlation is high and provide more precise estimates of the effect.

In total, 44 effect sizes from the 22 articles were calculated. Of the 44 included effects, 32 examined the signaling effect of blood glucose while the remaining 11 effect sizes were related to appetitive stimuli. Effect sizes were coded such that a positive effect indicates that the presence of a resource cue led to a lower discounting rate.

div.head: Data Analysis
div.p: Twelve out of 22 articles reported multiple effect sizes. To deal with the dependence between effects, we fitted two three-level random-effects meta-analysis models with a restricted maximum likelihood estimator, using the R package metafor (Viechtbauer, 2010). The heterogeneity across effects was evaluated using the Q test. THE EFFECTS OF RESOURCE CUES ON DELAY DISCOUNTING 10 A significant p value of the Q test rejects the null hypothesis of no heterogeneity. We further quantified the heterogeneity by calculating a multilevel version of 2 (Cheung, 2014). Typically, 2 indicates the proportion of the variation that is not attributed to sampling variance. In the three-level meta-analysis, we calculated the proportion of the variation due to the between-study heterogeneity ( 3 2) and to the within-study heterogeneity ( 2 2). Followeing by the overall effect, potential moderators of the glucose-delay discounting association were examined using threelevel mixed effect models.

Moderator analyses were only conducted for the effect of blood glucose due to the number of studies being adequate. We coded several moderators. First, the type of reward assessed whether the delay discounting task used food or nonfood rewards such as money. Second, we explored whether different operationalizations of blood glucose moderate the effect. The experimental manipulation was coded as glucose administration versus food deprivation. Finally, we decided to include the type of design (between-vs. within-subjects design) as a moderator. Previous studies suggested that delay discounting is trait-like (Odum, 2011). Therefore, for betweensubject designs in which the idiosyncrasy of delay discounting is not controlled, the blood glucose effect could be attenuated.
Publication bias and selective reporting were evaluated using three methods.

First, we generated a contour-enhanced funnel plots to determine whether there was any asymmetry of the plot and whether this was caused by publication bias (Peters et al., 2008). The funnel asymmetry was also tested using Egger's regression test (Egger THE EFFECTS OF RESOURCE CUES ON DELAY DISCOUNTING 11 et al., 1997). To avoid the unit-of-analysis error, dependent effects extracted from one study were aggregated before the analysis. Second, we conducted the PET-PEESE method without aggregating dependent effects to test publication bias (Stanley & Doucouliagos, 2014). When using the PET-PEESE method, we regressed the effect size on either its standard error or variance in order to obtain a true effect with a standard error/variance of zero (e.g., the intercept of the regression) that is not biased by the small-study effect that studies with greater variance can inflate the overall effect. Third, we conducted a p-curve analysis using the R package dmetar (Harrer et al., 2021) to ascertain whether the included studies contains evidential value (Simonsohn et al., 2015). The P-curve characterizes the distribution of the p values of the included studies that are statistically significant (p < .05). Right-skewed p-curves indicate evidential value, meaning that some observations are influenced by experimental manipulation (Simonsohn et al., 2014). On the contrary, when there is no true effect, the p-curve's shape is flat or uniform. To evaluate the presence of evidential value, we first conducted tests of right-skewness. Since the right-skewness test is subjected to statistical power, we also carried out tests for flatness to determine whether our data could reject the null hypothesis that the observed p-curve is not slightly right-skewed. Significant results indicate that the p-curve is significantly flatter than a very small effect and there is no evidential value. We did not examine potential publication bias and selective reporting for effects on appetitive stimuli since the number of studies is small.

div.head: THE EFFECTS OF RESOURCE CUES ON DELAY DISCOUNTING 12
Overall Effect Size
div.p: All the 44 effect sizes and the pooled effects are shown in Figure 1

div.head: Forest Plot of the Effects of Blood Glucose and Appetitive Stimuli
div.p: Notes. Bars and numbers in brackets denote 95% confidence intervals.

div.head: Moderator Analyses
div.p: A summary of moderation analyses was shown in Table 1. The type of reward in delay discounting tasks (food vs. non-food) has a significant moderation effect, ( = 1) = 11.35, p < .001. The signaling effect of glucose on delay discounting is stronger for food rewards than non-food rewards. We then examined whether food deprivation and glucose ingestion had comparable effect sizes. The type of THE EFFECTS OF RESOURCE CUES ON DELAY DISCOUNTING 14 manipulation (deprivation vs. glucose ingestion) did not explained the heterogeneity across effects, ( = 1) = 2.06, p = .15. We noticed that among all the 14 samples adopting a food-deprivation manipulation, only three reported negative effects and two of those extracted from the same study (Forzano et al., 2010) were extremely negative (-1.20 and -0.59). The results reported by Forzano et al. (2010) are hard to explained in the context of other studies. Once these two influential cases were removed, food deprivation exhibited a stronger effect than glucose ingestion, ( = 1) = 5.66, p = .017. However, this result was confounded by the effect of reward type because food rewards were only used in studies that operationalized blood glucose via food deprivation. To address this issue, we classified effects into three categories: (1) food rewards and food deprivation;
(2) nonfood rewards and food deprivation;

(3) nonfood rewards and glucose administration. If the type of manipulation has a moderation effect, we expected a significant difference between the second and third groups. The results showed that the latter two groups did not differ significantly, z = .52, p = .60. Therefore, the moderation effect of manipulation was confounded by the type of reward but not the other way around. In a third mixed effect model, the type of design was examined. Although studies using withinsubjects designs resulted in more positive effects, the result failed to reach significance, ( = 1) = 0.11, p = .74. a We noticed that the between-study heterogeneity differs greatly between groups (nonfood: 2 = 0.58; food: 2 = 0.08) and thus it is unreasonable to assume a common estimate of 2 . Therefore, we separately estimated the pooled effect as well as corresponding variance components for each subgroup. This result indicates that both food and nonfood rewards are influenced by the signaling effect of blood glucose.

div.head: Publication Bias and Selective Reporting
div.p: The contour-enhanced funnel plot (Figure 2 Egger's regression test was conducted. The intercept of the regression was not significantly different from zero, 0 =0.89, t = 0.66, p = 0.52, providing further evidence that there was no publication bias.
Next, we conducted PET-PEESE analyses without aggregating effect sizes.
The result showed that the intercept of PET was not significantly larger than zero.

Thus, we dropped the estimate of PEESE and reported the results of PET. The corrected overall effect was insignificant, 0 = 0.048, z = 0.18, p = .85, nor the regression coefficient of standard error, 1 = 0.79, z = 0.72, p = .47. Noted that the PET-PEESE performs badly (e.g., overcorrects for biases) when the number of studies is small and the heterogeneity is high (Carter et al., 2019). Therefore, the corrected effect therefore should be viewed with these considerations in mind.

div.head: Figure 2
div.p: Contour-Enhanced Funnel Plot on Studies Examining the Effect of Blood Glucose THE EFFECTS OF RESOURCE CUES ON DELAY DISCOUNTING

The p-curve analysis was conducted based on aggregated effect sizes ( Figure 3). Nine results of statistically significance (p < .05) were included. Two out of the three right-skewness tests were significant, the full p-curve pp-value test, z = -2.75, p = .003, the test based on the half p-curve, z = -1.71, p = .043. The binomial test was insignificant, p = .09. This could be attributed to its inherent drawback that it dichotomizes p-values before making statistical inferences when they are in fact continuous (Harrer et al., 2021). Based on the practical guidelines on interpreting pcurve's results (Simonsohn et al., 2015), at least some of our included studies have evidential evidence and the manipulation of blood glucose is effective.

Taken together, we concluded that the overall effect was not contaminated by publication bias and selective reporting. when there is no effect (a uniform distribution) and the green dashed line denotes the p-value distribution assuming 33% power.

div.head: Discussion
div.p: Recent studies have shown that levels of blood glucose, hunger sensations, and food cues have an impact on delay discounting. We argue that all these factors are resource cues connoting current body-energy budget and resource availability, providing forecasting signals that activate or deactivate needs for immediate resource acquisition. Our analyses revealed a small-to-medium positive effect of blood glucose THE EFFECTS OF RESOURCE CUES ON DELAY DISCOUNTING 19 but a negative effect of appetitive stimuli on delay discounting. Being satiated decreases delay discounting while exposure to appetitive cues increases it. Overall, organisms adaptively adjust their resource allocation strategies in the presence of environmental cues and internal signals that are relevant to survival.

With regard to the effect of blood glucose on delay discounting, we integrated more recent evidence and arrived at the conclusion that low levels of blood glucose increase delay discounting, replicating results of the previous review by Orquin and Kurzban (2016). Moreover, the effect is domain-specific, with a stronger effect for food. Dovetailing with the former meta-analysis, this moderation effect refutes the ego depletion model (Baumeister et al., 2007) that proposed a general decrease in self-control when hungry while favoring the energy-budget rule (Kacelnik & Bateson, 1997) and the resource signaling hypothesis (Wang, 2018). The two supported signal models imply that blood glucose is an important fuel for the body and organisms should be able to track its supply in a prospective manner in order to survive (Orquin & Kurzban, 2016). Therefore, the difference in delay discounting between in-domain (e.g., food) and out-of-domain rewards (e.g., money) are derived from the relevance of the reward in coping with the current situation (e.g., hunger), with a higher relevance being accompanied by higher delay discounting. The smaller effect in nonfood rewards (mostly money in our study) can be attributed to the finding that money is a derivative of food (Briers et al., 2006) and is fungible when mitigating hunger (Holt et al., 2016).

div.head: THE EFFECTS OF RESOURCE CUES ON DELAY DISCOUNTING 20
div.p: Our result is inconsistent with a recent meta-analysis which concluded that the effect of food deprivation on delay discounting is trivial (Downey et al., 2022), with several key differences being apparent. First, we excluded nonhuman samples but included more human samples that were omitted by their study. Second, Downey et al. hypothesized that water and food deprivation had similar effects and should be integrated. However, it has been found that the underpinning of the glucose signaling effect is the glucose-insulin system and should not be confused with water deprivation (Wang & Huangfu, 2017).

Nevertheless, Downey et al. (2022) agreed that the effect of deprivation is domain-specific, as there were no consistent effects across different types of deprivation. As they noted, this finding is against the competing neurobehavioral decision systems model (CNDS) (Bickel & Yi, 2008). According to the CNDS model, delay discounting is determined by an impulsive and an executive control system. When the impulsive system is hyperactive or the control system is hypoactive, emphasis is placed on immediate rewards. Deprivation could result in hypoactivity of the control system and hyperactivity in the impulsive system and thus increases delay discounting (Downey et al., 2022;Koffarnus & Woods, 2013). This prediction is not fully supported; for example, although one night of sleep deprivation impairs executive function (Skurvydas et al., 2020), Downey et al. (2022) did not find its impact on delay discounting. However, if people adaptively adjust delay discounting according to somatic cues, there should be no obvious effect of sleep deprivation on monetary delay discounting since allocating more money to the present is irrelevant to THE EFFECTS OF RESOURCE CUES ON DELAY DISCOUNTING 21 the problem at hand. Note that we are not challenging the CNDS model, but regarded it as less relevant in interpreting the present results. The CNDS model is supported by studies on smokers and addicts, who exhibited high discounting rates across domains (e.g., Field et al., 2007). Therefore, addicts are more likely subjected to the chronic effect of a hyperactive impulsive system, which could be domain-general.

Another major finding is that appetitive stimuli motivates participants to choose immediate rewards, lending support to the cephalic phase hypothesis (Forzano & Logue, 1994) and the dual signaling hypothesis of glucose effect (Wang, 2018).

Stimuli like the sweet taste of glucose indicate opportunities to acquire nutritious foods. Indeed, studies found that mere exposure to visual food increases neural activation in brain regions that are related to reward processing (e.g., lateral orbitofrontal cortex) (Pursey et al., 2014) and thus increase food consumption (Harris et al., 2009). Note that, in sharp contrast with other effects, one study reported a positive effect (Rao et al., 2015). Participants in this sample viewing photos of highcalorie food exhibited lower delay discounting. This indicates that we should not dismiss another explanation that, in some circumstances, food cues could induce satiety (Redden & Haws, 2013) and thus reduce delay discounting. For example, imagined food consumption reduces hunger and subsequent food intake (Morewedge et al., 2010). This could be a signal that the energy budget is sufficient and forecast less needs for immediate resource acquisition.

The opposing effects of glucose ingestion and appetitive stimuli might explain why the effect of blood glucose is small. Sweet flavors are inevitable during glucose THE EFFECTS OF RESOURCE CUES ON DELAY DISCOUNTING 22 ingestion. For other studies where meals were prepared for participants (e.g., Muda et al., 2021), appetitive stimuli such as olfactory cues are also accompanied. If the time interval between food consumption and delay discounting task is too short, the signaling effect of glucose could be offset.

One limitation of the analysis of appetitive stimuli is that we were unable to compare the effect between in-domain and out-of-domain commodities because all the included studies used monetary rewards. We predict that the signaling effect would be stronger for food rewards since food cues should directly activate the need for caloric resources.

In general, our discussion highlights the concept of domain specificity. There is still a debate on whether delay discounting is domain-specific since there is evidence for both domain independence (Jimura et al., 2011;Weatherly & Terrell, 2010) and domain dependence (Odum, 2011). These studies mainly calculate correlations of discounting rates across domains to reach their conclusions, but it must be noted that their distinction between domains is arbitrary. As a result, the dependence between domains could derive from the similarity across tasks while the independence could be attributed to differences in fungibility and perishability of the rewards. If this is true, it reveals less about the psychological underpinning of delay discounting. Domain specificity implies that the mind is comprised of distinct modules that have evolved to solve recurrent survival and reproduction challenges (Boyer & Barrett, 2015). Since a delay discounting task does not serve as a challenge per se, a better way to examine domain specificity is to inspect how the dynamic THE EFFECTS OF RESOURCE CUES ON DELAY DISCOUNTING 23 interplay between individuals' needs and the proximate cues regulates decisionmaking. Different motivational systems respond to these domain-specific cues and result in different decision preference across domains.
In conclusion, both embodied signals and external cues about resource situations serve as forecasting signals for regulating intertemporal decision-making.

Decreasing levels of blood glucose and exposure to appetitive stimuli prioritize the need for resource acquisition and cause people to devaluate future rewards. Future studies could examine and integrate the effect of other ecological cues (e.g., social status and sexual stimuli) on delay discounting and whether they have domainspecific effects.

figure.figDesc: . In the first random-effects model examining the relationship between blood glucose and delay discounting (k = 32), a small-to-medium effect was found, d = 0.26, 95% CI [0.06, 0.46], z = 2.53, p = .011. Therefore, consuming glucose decreases delay discounting. There was considerable heterogeneity across effects, Q(31) = 128.59, p < .001. The estimated variance components were model addressing the relationship between appetitive stimuli and delay discounting (k = 11), the relationship reversed, d = -0.28, 95% CI [-0.51, -0.05], z = -2.41, p = .016. Exposure to appetitive stimuli makes people more inclined to devaluate future rewards. The heterogeneity across effects is insignificant, Q(11) = 16.49, p = .12. figure.figDesc: Analysis on Studies Examining the Effect of Blood Glucose Notes. The blue solid line shows the observed p-curve. Nine statistically significant results were included, of which seven are p < .025. The red dotted line shows the distribution of p values

Since experimental studies were included, we chose the standardized mean difference (Cohen's d) as the effect size. We converted t values, F values, p values, and means and standard deviations to Cohen's d. If a study reported the result as significant at .05 level (p < .05), the p value was set to the upper bound (p = .05).
